finding: The SNP rs3751385 was previously assessed in relation to psoriasis vulgaris, highlighting its significance as a genetic polymorphism that may influence the disease. The context of this finding relates to the understanding of how genetic variations could interact with host factors, such as immune response, which is crucial in the pathogenesis of psoriasis.
title: Interactions of host defense and hyper-keratinization in psoriasis

finding: The SNP rs921058 was identified within cCREs linked to the HLA-DRB1 gene, which was significantly down-regulated in microglia in the EC region of sEOAD. This indicated its importance in the genetic landscape contributing to sEOAD and LOAD.
title: Single-nucleus multiomics reveals the disrupted regulatory programs in three brain regions of sporadic early-onset Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The SNP rs57438463 was located in the promoter region of the ZDHHC20 gene in oligodendrocytes, where it was associated with a significant upregulation of ZDHHC20 expression in HIP samples of sEOAD patients, suggesting its involvement in the pathophysiology of the disease.
title: Single-nucleus multiomics reveals the disrupted regulatory programs in three brain regions of sporadic early-onset Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The SNP rs4143229 showed an association with depression only, residing within an intron of the ENOX1 gene, which is expressed in the nervous system and associated with autoimmune disorders.
title: Stratifying depression by neuroticism: revisiting a diagnostic tradition using GWAS data

finding: The SNP rs1343605 was linked exclusively to depression and is situated near the OLFM4 gene, which has connections to depression, inflammation, and cancer.
title: Stratifying depression by neuroticism: revisiting a diagnostic tradition using GWAS data

finding: The SNP rs150191017 also achieved genome-wide significance with a P-value of 3.77 × 10^-8. It was located 31.5 kb from the gene AL161616.2, previously associated with venlafaxine treatment response in generalized anxiety disorder.
title: Retrospective Association Analysis of Longitudinal Binary Traits Identifies Important Loci and Pathways in Cocaine Use

finding: The SNP rs116855232, which represents a missense variant in the NUDT15 gene leading to the Arg139 substitution by Cys, was found to be associated with the accumulation of 6-mercaptopurine metabolites. This accumulation resulted in cellular toxicity and was linked to thiopurine-induced leukopenia during thiopurine treatments, indicating its relevance in clinical prognosis.
title: Molecular dynamics simulations reveal the impact of NUTD15 variants in structural conformation and dynamics

finding: Located upstream of the ZMYM2 gene, the SNP rs7982701 was associated with morphology-related traits such as body mass index and adult body size, indicating its influence on physical characteristics that may also correlate with brain morphology.
title: A novel classification framework for genome-wide association study of whole brain MRI images using deep learning

finding: The SNP rs117135638 in the essential gene EXOSC8, resulting in a C to A substitution causing a proline to histidine change, was also recognized as a viable target for cancer therapy. This SNP had a heterozygosity rate of 2% and underwent LOH in 29% of cancer types, with a particularly high occurrence in lung squamous cell carcinomas (72%). Similar to PRIM1, allele-specific disruption approaches confirmed that cells with the sensitive C allele (EXOSC8^S) showed reduced growth when targeted, while cells with the resistant A allele (EXOSC8^R) did not exhibit decreased viability.
title: Loss of heterozygosity of essential genes represents a widespread class of potential cancer vulnerabilities

finding: The haplotype containing rs139514105, referred to as c.-493del10, in 5'UTR of NM_004004.5 was confirmed in an affected sibling pair from the UK and among seven affected individuals from Germany. This linkage suggested a potential association with the pathogenic variants Met34Thr and Val37Ile in GJB2, both of which were found to be significantly overrepresented in hearing loss patients compared to the general population. The relationship between this haplotype and hearing loss supports its relevance, despite the absence of findings indicating that it abolishes GJB2 expression.
title: Consensus interpretation of the Met34Thr and Val37Ile variants in GJB2 by the ClinGen Hearing Loss Expert Panel

finding: The SNP rs11838776 in the COL4A2 gene was also linked to coronary artery disease, further detailing genetic influences on cardiovascular conditions.
title: Screening and identification of key biomarkers in diabetic kidney disease and its complications: Evidence from bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The lead SNP rs139309608 on chromosome 13 was associated with the horizontal component of brain asymmetry. This SNP, located within an intron of the gene TMEM255B, had a minor allele frequency of 0.17% and an additive effect for the T allele was -5.49 with a highly significant p-value of 4.01e-08.
title: Handedness and Other Variables Associated with Human Brain Asymmetrical Skew

finding: The SNP rs61736969 was identified as the causal variant in the TBC1D4 gene associated with high risk of type 2 diabetes and elevated 2-hour plasma glucose levels in the Greenlandic population. This finding was consistent between different analyses, showing that the effect in the Greenlandic population did not differ from standard tests.
title: Ancestry-specific association mapping in admixed populations

finding: The SNP rs7330796 served as the lead SNP in the initial discovery phase of the study. It was strongly associated with increased 2-hour plasma glucose levels, but later analysis showed that its effect varied based on ancestral inheritance, indicating it was not causal despite being a significant marker.
title: Ancestry-specific association mapping in admixed populations

finding: The SNP rs1062087 was one of the four non-causal SNPs analyzed for association with 2-hour plasma glucose levels. As with rs7330796, its effect was found to depend on whether alleles were inherited from the ancestral Inuit population, supporting the hypothesis that it is not causal.
title: Ancestry-specific association mapping in admixed populations

finding: Similar to rs1062087, the SNP rs2297206 was identified as a non-causal variant that showed more significant effects when both alleles were of Inuit ancestry. This finding aligned with the study's results indicating its non-causal nature.
title: Ancestry-specific association mapping in admixed populations

finding: The SNP rs77685055 also demonstrated a stronger recessive effect when both alleles were inherited from the Inuit population. Consequently, it was classified as a non-causal variant, in accordance with the findings of the study.
title: Ancestry-specific association mapping in admixed populations

finding: The variant rs9513900 was identified as genome-wide significant in association with CF lung disease, with a minimal p-value of 3.12×10−8. This variant was annotated between the genes ITGBL1 and NALCN on chromosome 13 and exhibited a minor allele frequency (MAF) of 0.31. It was not previously reported in earlier meta-GWAS of CF lung disease, suggesting it is a novel contributor to the disease. The variant had a positive overall effect on pulmonary phenotypes, with median and mean effects of 0.054 and 0.046 respectively, indicating a 5.4% increase in lung phenotype with the presence of the variant. Additionally, significant evidence for rs9513900 as an expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) for NALCN was found, with a Bonferroni corrected p-value of 1×10−3.
title: A robust association test leveraging unknown genetic interactions: Application to cystic fibrosis lung disease

finding: The rs3742305 was identified as the lead candidate causal variant impacting T2D and BMI in the chr13:31036642-31116642 locus, influencing the isoform usage of HMGB1 in pancreas development.
title: eQTL mapping in fetal-like pancreatic progenitor cells reveals early developmental insights into diabetes risk

finding: The SNP rs56314249, overlapping the FLT1 gene, was identified as a coding variant showing evidence of positive selection. However, it was a synonymous variant that did not lead to an amino acid change, complicating the interpretation of its adaptive significance.
title: Archaic Adaptive Introgression in Modern Human Reproductive Genes

finding: SNP rs11843418 was identified as one of the strongest associations in the GWAS analysis. It had been previously reported in earlier studies related to diverticular disease, highlighting its potential impact on disease risk and phenotype.
title: Multi-ancestry Genome- and Phenome-wide Association Studies of Diverticular Disease in Electronic Health Records with Natural Language Processing enriched phenotype algorithm

finding: The SNP rs9565028 demonstrated significant associations with genitourinary manifestations, particularly 'functional disorders of bladder' and 'other disorders of bladder'. This association was reported in both major ancestry (MA) and European ancestry (EA) PheWAS analyses.
title: Multi-ancestry Genome- and Phenome-wide Association Studies of Diverticular Disease in Electronic Health Records with Natural Language Processing enriched phenotype algorithm

finding: The SNP rs11838776, found intronically in the COL4A2 gene, showed significant association with PVWMH and is previously linked to coronary artery disease.
title: Common genetic variation indicates separate etiologies for periventricular and deep white matter hyperintensities

finding: The SNP rs55940034 was associated with the COL4A2 gene, showing significant results for PVWMH and has been previously reported in relation to myocardial infarction.
title: Common genetic variation indicates separate etiologies for periventricular and deep white matter hyperintensities

finding: The SNP rs9515201 was found in high linkage disequilibrium with the study's top finding in COL4A2 for total WMH burden and confirmed significant findings for PVWMH.
title: Common genetic variation indicates separate etiologies for periventricular and deep white matter hyperintensities

finding: The SNP rs12020259 was initially identified in relation to Rab GTPases, suggests that variations at this locus could play a role in the regulation of survival pathways in cancer. This finding was noted in the context of the research that outlines the functional roles of Rab11 and Rab35, which are implicated in cancer cell division and cytokinesis. The study highlighted that this SNP associates with aberrant levels of key proteins involved in cell cycle regulation.
title: The unique contributions of Rab11 and Rab35 to the completion of cell division

finding: The SNP rs80338851, which corresponds to c.660+1G>A, was identified as the most common mutation associated with Peters plus syndrome (PPS). This indicates a significant relationship between this SNP and the development of PPS.
title: In Silico Analysis of B3GALTL Gene Reveling 13 Novel Mutations Associated with Peters’-plus syndrome

finding: SNP rs7998201 was found to be significantly associated with TEX30 expression levels, influenced by the methylation levels at a CpG site at chr13:102826051. Although rs7998201 did not serve as an eQTL for TEX30 or a meQTL for the associated CpG site, its interaction with the meCpG site was shown to modulate the relationship between the SNP and gene expression.
title: memo-eQTL: DNA methylation modulated genetic variant effect on gene transcriptional regulation

finding: The SNP rs12020259 was associated with the expression changes in secretory pathway components across different cancer types. The study aimed to identify genes linked to tumor characteristics such as mutation of p53 and tumor stage. This association highlighted the potential role of genes impacted by this SNP in tumor progression and development, particularly within the context of the secretory pathway's dysfunction in cancer.
title: Machine learning-based investigation of the cancer protein secretory pathway

finding: The SNP rs7987944 was connected to a trans pQTL influencing the protein TALDO1, which is involved in metabolic pathways, thus relevant to AF.
title: Tissue-specific multiOMICs analysis of atrial fibrillation

finding: As an intronic variant in DGKH, rs1037271 was predicted to influence CaSR signaling, thus contributing to the understanding of genetic factors in kidney stone disease.
title: Genetic variants of calcium and vitamin D metabolism in kidney stone disease

finding: The SNP rs238256 was identified as having trans-interchromosomal connections to RAD21, specifically involved in the regulation of AKAP11 transcript levels. This discovery highlighted a significant role of this SNP in influencing gene expression relevant to cancer, as AKAP11 has been associated with cancer pathology.
title: Genetic Variation as a Long-Distance Modulator of RAD21 Expression in Humans

finding: Deduced that rs4771268 was the lead GWAS SNP within the MBNL2 locus, overlapping with oligodendrocyte-specific enhancers and reinforcing the gene MBNL2's potential causal role in PD, reflecting a newfound acknowledgment of oligodendrocytes in the pathogenesis of PD.
title: Fine-mapping of Parkinson’s disease susceptibility loci identifies putative causal variants

finding: The study identified a significant association between the SNP rs6313 in the HTR2A gene and sleep bruxism (SB). This SNP was found to contribute to altered electrophysiological characteristics in human induced pluripotent stem cell (hiPSC)-derived neurons from patients exhibiting the C/C genotype, which is associated with increased excitability. Specifically, the findings indicated that SB neurons had shorter action potential half durations and exhibited a 2-fold higher firing frequency compared to control neurons, highlighting potential mechanisms underlying the neurological aspects of SB.
title: Electrophysiological maturation and increased excitability of human iPSC-derived neurons in HTR2A variant-related sleep bruxism

finding: The study identified rs764288814, also known as C231Y, which involved a mutation where Cysteine was changed to Tyrosine at position 231 of the FLT3 gene. This SNP was considered damaging and was linked to acute myeloid leukemia (AML) pathogenesis.
title: Twenty novel nsSNPs may affect FLT3 gene leading to Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) using in silico analysis

finding: For rs887807138, there were two relevant mutations described: C681 and C681Y, where Cysteine was switched to Serine and Tyrosine at position 681, respectively. This SNP was classified as damaging and implicated in AML development.
title: Twenty novel nsSNPs may affect FLT3 gene leading to Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) using in silico analysis

finding: The SNP rs1221467960, referred to as C694R, resulted in the mutation of Cysteine to Arginine at position 694. This was another damaging SNP related to FLT3 mutations in AML.
title: Twenty novel nsSNPs may affect FLT3 gene leading to Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) using in silico analysis

finding: The mutation at rs1361689773, known as C925Y, involved the transition from Cysteine to Tyrosine at position 925 in the FLT3 gene. It was identified as one of the damaging SNPs affecting AML.
title: Twenty novel nsSNPs may affect FLT3 gene leading to Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) using in silico analysis

finding: rs1474119276, or D787Y, indicated a substitution where Aspartic acid was altered to Tyrosine at position 787. This mutation was categorized as damaging and linked to leukemia pathology.
title: Twenty novel nsSNPs may affect FLT3 gene leading to Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) using in silico analysis

finding: The SNP rs776952835, labeled as E880A, involved the change from Glutamic acid to Alanine at position 880. It was recognized as damaging and relevant to FLT3 gene mutations in AML.
title: Twenty novel nsSNPs may affect FLT3 gene leading to Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) using in silico analysis

finding: The study highlighted rs537215681, termed F349C, which involved a mutation from Phenylalanine to Cysteine at position 349. This SNP was identified as damaging and associated with acute myeloid leukemia.
title: Twenty novel nsSNPs may affect FLT3 gene leading to Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) using in silico analysis

finding: Under rs1442266284, two mutations were examined: G619D, wherein Phenylalanine mutations occurred to Cysteine at position 619, and G885V, changing Glycine to Valine at position 885. Both mutations were categorized as damaging and implicated in FLT3 and AML.
title: Twenty novel nsSNPs may affect FLT3 gene leading to Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) using in silico analysis

finding: The rs774360726 SNP, referred to as L860P, indicated a change from Leucine to Proline at position 860. It was recognized as a damaging alteration relevant to FLT3 gene function in AML.
title: Twenty novel nsSNPs may affect FLT3 gene leading to Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) using in silico analysis

finding: The SNP rs200909894, denoted as M908V, involved the mutation from Methionine to Valine at position 908. This SNP was part of the damaging mutations studied in acute myeloid leukemia.
title: Twenty novel nsSNPs may affect FLT3 gene leading to Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) using in silico analysis

finding: The analysis revealed rs974980406, or M922T, noting the switch from Methionine to Threonine at position 922. This SNP was considered damaging with implications in AML.
title: Twenty novel nsSNPs may affect FLT3 gene leading to Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) using in silico analysis

finding: For rs142796469, the findings covered two mutations: P890R, which mutated Proline to Arginine at position 890, and V624A, where Valine was altered to Alanine at position 624. Both were judged as damaging snps linked to FLT3 gene and AML.
title: Twenty novel nsSNPs may affect FLT3 gene leading to Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) using in silico analysis

finding: The SNP rs1276477642, identified as V643D, involved the mutation of Valine to Aspartic acid at position 643, categorizing it as a damaging SNP related to the pathology of acute myeloid leukemia.
title: Twenty novel nsSNPs may affect FLT3 gene leading to Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) using in silico analysis

finding: The study addressed rs1041412646, known as W383C, which resulted in the mutation from Tryptophan to Cysteine at position 383. This SNP was classified as damaging and relevant to FLT3 gene mutations.
title: Twenty novel nsSNPs may affect FLT3 gene leading to Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) using in silico analysis

finding: For rs774511256, the mutation denoted Y702C involved a change from Tyrosine to Cysteine at position 702. It was categorized as damaging and connected to FLT3 gene alterations.
title: Twenty novel nsSNPs may affect FLT3 gene leading to Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) using in silico analysis

finding: The SNP rs759638195, known as Y865C, involved the transition from Tyrosine to Cysteine at position 865. This was assessed as a damaging alteration related to acute myeloid leukemia.
title: Twenty novel nsSNPs may affect FLT3 gene leading to Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) using in silico analysis

finding: Lastly, rs868802040, termed Y874C, involved a mutation from Tyrosine to Cysteine at position 874. This SNP was recognized as damaging and relevant to the FLT3 gene's role in AML.
title: Twenty novel nsSNPs may affect FLT3 gene leading to Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) using in silico analysis

finding: The variant rs114066381-A was significantly associated with Body Mass Index (BMI) and fat mass index specifically in females from the Pelotas cohort, demonstrating one of the strongest female-specific effects ever reported (beta=3.99±0.84 kg/m² per allele). This finding was replicated in other cohorts, confirming its relevance in morbid obesity.
title: Admixture/fine-mapping in Brazilians reveals a West African associated potential regulatory variant (rs114066381) with a strong female-specific effect on body mass- and fat mass-indexes

finding: This SNP, within the MTUS2 gene, was associated with obesity-related traits, corroborating its relevance in BMI among females in the studied cohorts.
title: Admixture/fine-mapping in Brazilians reveals a West African associated potential regulatory variant (rs114066381) with a strong female-specific effect on body mass- and fat mass-indexes

finding: Associated with MPN risk (joint p = 6.3 × 10^-9) and located in an intron of FOXO1, this SNP suggested a role in HSC self-renewal processes.
title: Genetic predisposition to myeloproliferative neoplasms implicates hematopoietic stem cell biology

finding: The SNP rs9585056 was identified within the lncRNA ARGI (Antiviral Response Gene Inducer) rather than being intergenic as previously thought. This SNP was linked to type 1 diabetes (T1D) and was shown to affect the secondary structure of ARGI, disrupting its functional capabilities. Additionally, the presence of the risk allele (rs9585056-G) resulted in a stronger interaction between ARGI and CTCF, enhancing the transcriptional activation of antiviral and pro-inflammatory genes in pancreatic beta cells upon viral infections.
title: The type 1 diabetes-associated lncRNA ARGI participates in virus-induced pancreatic β cell inflammation

finding: The stop-gain variant rs11571833 located in BRCA2 (p.K3326*) was recognized as deleterious and was part of the findings that connected to breast cancer risk. It contributed to the previously identified deleterious changes among risk variants.
title: Fine-mapping of 150 breast cancer risk regions identifies 178 high confidence target genes

finding: The SNP rs7324564 represented a novel risk variant discovered in this study, implying its potential role in the genetic risk for mood disorders.
title: Multivariate GWAS of psychiatric disorders and their cardinal symptoms reveal two dimensions of cross-cutting genetic liabilities

finding: The SNP rs146350366 was significantly associated with sporadic miscarriage in a European ancestry meta-analysis. It had a minor allele frequency (MAF) of 1.2% and a meta-analysis P-value of 3.2×10^-8. The association was linked to genetic variation near the FGF9 gene, which is involved in pregnancy maintenance and progesterone production.
title: The genetic architecture of sporadic and recurrent miscarriage

finding: The SNP rs76559378 at 13q13 demonstrated a p-value of 9.74 x 10^-7 and was in strong linkage disequilibrium with rs201936594, which had a high CADD score of 13.94, suggesting a likely deleterious effect. This association with RBC deformability illustrated its potential role in influencing red blood cell-related phenotypes.
title: Splenic clearance of rigid erythrocytes as an inherited mechanism for splenomegaly and natural resistance to malaria

finding: SNP rs201936594, being in strong linkage disequilibrium with rs76559378, exhibited a significant association with RBC deformability through its potentially deleterious effects indicated by a high CADD score. This finding provided insights into genetic factors that could affect red blood cell properties in populations.
title: Splenic clearance of rigid erythrocytes as an inherited mechanism for splenomegaly and natural resistance to malaria

finding: Identified as a variant in the 3' UTR of the lncRNA AL136961.1, rs9585056 was selected over rs9517719, despite no conclusive data confirming its causal relationship. It was part of the refined credible set while dropping its intergenic counterpart.
title: Improving the coverage of credible sets in Bayesian genetic fine-mapping

finding: Found in the PIBF1 gene, rs111440455 was significantly associated with serum creatinine levels, supporting its role in kidney-related issues and linking it to Joubert syndrome.
title: Mendelian pathway analysis of laboratory traits reveals distinct roles for ciliary subcompartments in common disease pathogenesis

finding: Similar to rs1015250, this SNP also displayed a significant frequency and heterozygosity value, indicating its importance in genetic analysis.
title: The forensic landscape and the population genetic analyses of Hainan Li based on massively parallel sequencing DNA profiling

finding: This SNP supported the existing GWAS annotation, contributing to refinement of gene assignment through QTL data.
title: Interpreting coronary artery disease GWAS results: A functional genomics approach assessing biological significance

finding: The SNP rs9543733, situated in an intergenic locus near LINC00347 on chromosome 13, was associated with thalamus variability. It showed borderline significance, with a p-value of 6.4×10^-8 and accounted for 0.055% of the variance, also consistent among healthy individuals.
title: Genetic control of variability in subcortical and intracranial volumes

finding: The SNP rs1924074 was part of ten GWAS SNPs linked to a chromatin loop regulating PDX1, crucial for maintaining beta-cell function.
title: INFIMA leverages multi-omics model organism data to identify effector genes of human GWAS variants

finding: This SNP was associated with the regulation of PDX1 and intronic regions of MTIF3 shown to influence type 2 diabetes mechanisms.
title: INFIMA leverages multi-omics model organism data to identify effector genes of human GWAS variants

finding: Like rs9581853, this SNP was part of several variants associated with PDX1, implicating its function in gene regulatory networks affecting type 2 diabetes.
title: INFIMA leverages multi-omics model organism data to identify effector genes of human GWAS variants

finding: SNP rs9319366 was linked to regulatory elements of PDX1 as part of the analysis revealing connections to diabetes susceptibility.
title: INFIMA leverages multi-omics model organism data to identify effector genes of human GWAS variants

finding: This SNP was indicated as influencing PDX1 regulatory mechanisms through interactions with multiple GWAS SNPs related to beta-cell function.
title: INFIMA leverages multi-omics model organism data to identify effector genes of human GWAS variants

finding: Part of the chromatin loop impacting PDX1 expression, SNP rs4771122 contributed to insights into type 2 diabetes risk factors.
title: INFIMA leverages multi-omics model organism data to identify effector genes of human GWAS variants

finding: Linked with PDX1 and its regulatory pathways, this SNP was shown to be involved in genetic predisposition to type 2 diabetes.
title: INFIMA leverages multi-omics model organism data to identify effector genes of human GWAS variants

finding: SNP rs12585587 was associated with regulatory elements affecting PDX1 expression and thus implicated in beta-cell function.
title: INFIMA leverages multi-omics model organism data to identify effector genes of human GWAS variants

finding: This SNP was included among the genetic variants linked to PDX1 regulation, reflecting its significance in the diabetes context.
title: INFIMA leverages multi-omics model organism data to identify effector genes of human GWAS variants

finding: Associated with PDX1 and noted within the context of several variants connected to the beta-cell function, implicating its importance in type 2 diabetes.
title: INFIMA leverages multi-omics model organism data to identify effector genes of human GWAS variants

finding: The SNP rs4304924 correlated with differential regulatory activity and allele specific expression of POU4F1, with the G allele mutating a homeobox transcription factor motif and exhibiting reduced POU4F1 expression linked to Large Artery Stroke and Pulse Pressure.
title: Functional non-coding SNPs in human endothelial cells fine-map vascular trait associations

finding: The rs1455609180 SNP leads to a K32T mutation and was also found to increase nucleation in the context of the ADan peptide. Like R9Q, it suggests a contribution to the disease mechanism associated with Danish dementia.
title: Deep mutagenesis reveals the distinct mutational landscape of ADan and ABri amyloid nucleation

finding: The SNP rs578006622, leading to the A7S mutation, was found to increase nucleation of the ABri peptide. This suggests that it may have implications for the mechanisms underlying British dementia.
title: Deep mutagenesis reveals the distinct mutational landscape of ADan and ABri amyloid nucleation

finding: The SNP rs139394220 causes an I8V mutation which was identified to enhance the nucleation of the ABri peptide, indicating a potential pathogenic role in British dementia.
title: Deep mutagenesis reveals the distinct mutational landscape of ADan and ABri amyloid nucleation

finding: For SNP rs1428007068, the L20S mutation was shown to increase nucleation of the ABri peptide, further implicating it in mechanisms related to British dementia.
title: Deep mutagenesis reveals the distinct mutational landscape of ADan and ABri amyloid nucleation

finding: The rs760120359 SNP, resulting in a K28R mutation, was also found to increase nucleation of the ABri peptide, reinforcing its potential role in the pathology of British dementia.
title: Deep mutagenesis reveals the distinct mutational landscape of ADan and ABri amyloid nucleation

finding: The tumor marker variant rs80358920 was identified in individual S9, exhibiting a genotype likelihood of 0.999 and was noted to be prevalent only in modern Asian populations, providing insights into the individual's possible ancestral ties.
title: Interdisciplinary analyses of Bronze Age communities from Western Hungary reveal complex population histories

finding: The variant rs1328363 was associated with refraction error and myopia as a sc-eQTL of GPC6, a sc-caQTL of its residing OCR, and a sc-ASCA in Rod. It strengthened the binding of CRX, a photoreceptor-specific TF.
title: Integrative single cell multiomics analysis of human retina indicates a role for hierarchical transcription factors collaboration in genetic effects on gene regulation

finding: The Klotho gene polymorphism rs495392 was associated with a protective effect against hepatic steatosis in patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, indicating its relevance in metabolic disorders.
title: Identification of novel prognostic targets in acute kidney injury using bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: This SNP was identified in associations linking to TN disease (P<sub>TN</sub> associated; solidifying its role in HR-negative features.
title: Common breast cancer risk loci predispose to distinct tumor subtypes

finding: The SNP rs79552930 was reported to have an association with lincRNA RP11-290F20.3 in FCGR3A+ monocytes, reinforcing its role in gene regulation.
title: Expression QTLs in single-cell sequencing data

finding: The C-allele of rs4769613, located near the FLT1 locus, was identified as a high-confidence placental risk factor for preeclampsia. This finding was significant as it correlated with the crucial role of the FLT1 enhancer in cardiovascular development, where disruptions could lead to vascular defects and related complications.
title: The human FLT1 regulatory element directs vascular expression and modulates angiogenesis pathways in vitro and in vivo

finding: The lead SNP rs573983368 was an intronic variant in the DACH1 gene, exhibiting an age-dependent effect on white matter cerebrum volume change. DACH1 gene is crucial for regulating gene expression and cell fate during development, particularly highly expressed in neuroprogenitor cells.
title: Dynamics of Brain Structure and its Genetic Architecture over the Lifespan

finding: The human IFITM3 rs12552-C SNP was proposed to result in IFITM3 plasma membrane localization and was identified as a risk factor for severe COVID-19. This finding suggested that this SNP could significantly influence the severity of SARS-CoV-2 infections.
title: Opposing activities of IFITM proteins in SARS-CoV-2 infection

finding: The frameshift variant <italic>35delG</italic> (rs80338939) was positively identified as accounting for 60% of <italic>GJB2</italic> autosomal recessive variants in White cases in a large US-based study, indicating a strong association with non-syndromic hearing loss.
title: A general model for two-locus assortative mating analysis and prediction

finding: The missense substitution <italic>101T >C</italic> (also known as <italic>M34T</italic>, rs35887622) accounted for 12% of <italic>GJB2</italic> autosomal recessive variants in White cases of non-syndromic hearing loss, illustrating its relevance but lower impact compared to <italic>35delG</italic>.
title: A general model for two-locus assortative mating analysis and prediction

finding: The variant <italic>167delT</italic> (rs80338942) was identified as the most common variant in the Ashkenazi Jewish population associated with autosomal recessive non-syndromic hearing loss, indicating its significant prevalence in this demographic.
title: A general model for two-locus assortative mating analysis and prediction

finding: The SNP rs72474224 C>T in the gene GJB2 was associated with deafness, autosomal recessive 1A, which exhibited a carrier frequency of 17.2% (1 in 6) in the Vietnamese population, significantly higher than those reported in Western populations.
title: Genetic landscape of recessive diseases in the Vietnamese population from large-scale clinical exome sequencing

finding: The pQTL rs4512994 was identified as having a known association with bone mineral density, highlighting its role in phenotypic traits.
title: Cross-platform proteomics to advance genetic prioritisation strategies

finding: The rs6563275 SNP was positively associated with the lactose digestion phenotype in the Fulani population. In a Genome Wide Association Study (GWAS), it exhibited a significant association with a p-value of 1.03 x 10^-6 and an effect size of 38.7%. This SNP also contributed to a combined effect size of 59.2% when analyzed alongside the T-13910 SNP, demonstrating its relevance to glucose levels in the bloodstream after lactose ingestion. However, the region containing the rs6563275 did not display any signals of recent selection in scans against the Yoruba population.
title: Population history and genetic adaptation of the Fulani nomads: Inferences from genome-wide data and the lactase persistence trait

finding: The SNP rs11571833 was identified in a breast cancer susceptibility GWAS with a p-value of 2 x 10^-6. The finding related to breast cancer risk was considered significant based on prior knowledge of the BRCA2 gene, known for its role as a tumor suppressor involved in DNA repair. The evidence suggested that this SNP was likely a true finding, indicating a potential association with increased breast cancer risk.
title: Priors, population sizes, and power in genome-wide hypothesis tests

finding: The SNP rs1021188, located on chromosome 13, was linked to cortical porosity, indicating a specific association with cortical bone parameters. This highlighted the differences in genetic factors influencing cortical and trabecular bone.
title: Genetic dissection of femoral and tibial microarchitecture

finding: This variant caused a new PAS motif within the TNFSF13B gene and was linked to a higher risk of multiple sclerosis and SLE in the Sardinian population, emphasizing its relevance in disease mechanisms.
title: The genetic determinants of the relative expression of alternative 3’UTR isoforms in human

finding: The missense variant rs80359104, which corresponds to the c.8524C>T (p.R2842C) mutation in the BRCA2 gene, was identified as a significant finding. This variant was correlated with primary ovarian insufficiency (POI), exhibiting a homozygous state in the studied patient from a consanguineous background. The variant was absent in unrelated fertile controls and had a very low minor allele frequency (MAF 1.10^-5), indicating its rarity. Moreover, it was predicted to be pathogenic by a majority (16 out of 17) of predictive softwares, suggesting a critical role in fertility and genome maintenance during meiotic processes.
title: A homozygous hypomorphic BRCA2 variant causes primary ovarian insufficiency without cancer or Fanconi anemia traits

finding: The SNP rs9533799 located in the lncRNA SMIM2-AS1 was found to be up-regulated in excitatory neurons when comparing ALS patients to the neuronal population from non-pathological conditions (PN). This finding suggested that SMIM2-AS1 may play a role in the dysregulated cellular processes associated with ALS.
title: Transcriptional profiling of human brain cortex identifies novel lncRNA-mediated networks dysregulated in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis

finding: The SNP rs9581943 demonstrated relevance to pancreatic cancer risk, further establishing connections in similar genetic studies.
title: Genome-wide association meta-analysis identifies novel GP2 gene risk variants for pancreatic cancer in the Japanese population

finding: The SNP rs9543325 was found to be genome-wide significant in this analysis, marking it as an important factor in pancreatic cancer risk.
title: Genome-wide association meta-analysis identifies novel GP2 gene risk variants for pancreatic cancer in the Japanese population
